title: Gunman opens fire at vigil held for victims of mass shooting
text:
Bullets were fired during a vigil held for shooting victims at a Halloween in Texas (Picture: EPA – AP)

Mourners ran for their lives after a gunman opened fire during a vigil for people killed in a mass shooting at a university party.

A gunman opened fire at the vigil in Greenville, near Dallas, Texas, hitting a news truck three times during the service on Sunday night.

It was organised after two people were killed at a university Halloween homecoming party for Texas A&M students on Saturday.

Police are still looking for the shooters, with the first attacker understood to have escaped during the chaos.

NBC Dallas-Fort Worth Diana Zoga was at the vigil and said: ‘Our news unit was hit at least three times,’ adding she had not seen anyone injured.

Authorities believe the attacker responsible for Saturday’s shooting may have been targeting one person, with the victims hit by random shots, Hunt County Sheriff Randy Meeks said.

It is thought the gunman entered the party through the back door and opened fire.

When the shots rang out ‘complete chaos’ descended with hundreds fleeing.

Of the 12 injured, six were trampled or hurt by glass in the ensuing melee, according a spokesman for the sheriff’s department.

Six others were injured by gunfire. Four are critical and one was said to be in a good condition as of Sunday afternoon. The status of the sixth person was not known.

Hunt County Sheriff Randy Meeks, centre, addresses members of the media at the sheriff’s department headquarters after the deadly shootings in Greenville, Texas, on Sunday October 27 ( Picture: The Dallas Morning News via AP)

The two people killed were both males, Sheriff Meeks said, with Kevin Berry Jr, 23, of Dallas, having been named in local media as one of the dead.

Authorities were still looking for the as-yet-unidentified suspect.

The following morning Halloween masks and other debris were strewn about and pools of blood seen on the ground.

Kimberly Wilson, 46, said her daughter, 19, had travelled to the party from Dallas.

She said: ‘She’s angry, hurt, upset. She’s going through that whole emotional thing. When you’ve not been trained to deal with something like that – it just throws you off.’

Sheriff Meeks praised the patrol sergeant and deputy at the scene saying his officers had quickly determined one gunshot victim had life-threatening injuries and got them hospital, while the deputy triaged others until paramedics arrived.

description: Gunfire at Greenville vigil held for victims of Texas A&M mass shooting
